word:
Brother M was so reduced by poor food and by want of conveniences and proper, careful attention while absent from his family, that he had no strength to 
                                                                           128
withstand exposure and disease.  He died a martyr to misconceived, crooked ideas of what constitutes health reform and self-denial.  He always had little thought for his own convenience, and was left too much to himself, to care for himself.  He was willing to do anything to save means.  Such conscientious souls are the ones who are hurt by these overstrained ideas of what constitutes health reform.
